Congo, Democratic Republic of - Economic
            Recovery and Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credits;
            Congo, Republic of - Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation
            and Economic Recovery Credits

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings of the Project Performance
            Assessment Report (PPAR) generally concur with the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings, except in
            the following instances: ratings for the Assessment of the
            Economic Recovery Credit Project are as follows: outcome
            (ICR highly satisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory); bank
            performance (ICR satisfactory, PPAR moderately
            unsatisfactory); borrower performance (ICR highly
            satisfactory, PPAR moderately unsatisfactory). Ratings for
            the Assessment of the Post-Reunification Economic Recovery
            Credit Project are as follows: outcome (ICR unsatisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); borrower and bank performance (ICR
            unsatisfactory, PPAR moderately unsatisfactory).Ratings for
            the Assessment of the Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation
            Credit Project are as follows: outcome (ICR satisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); bank performance (ICR satisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); borrower performance (ICR
            satisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory). Ratings for the
            Assessment of the Economic Recovery Credit Project are as
            follows: outcome (ICR unsatisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory);
            borrower and bank performance (ICR moderately
            unsatisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory). Some lessons learned
            included:  deep reforms changing the patterns of governance
            and public sector management require adequate preparation,
            including political economy assessment, consensus building
            effort and wide political and social ownership. In the
            absence of such thorough preparation, the likelihood of
            success is low, irrespective of potentially huge long-run
            gains for the country and society. In the post-conflict
            environment, a development policy operation (DPO) instrument
            can be effective if the reform program is well calibrated to
            a context of weak technical capacity and multiple
            priorities. In both countries, and for each operation,
            ownership of reforms was permanently elusive, and was only
            assured fleetingly by the lure of arrears clearance or debt
            relief. Ownership of reforms by respective governments
            followed a pattern of temporary commitment to reforms for
            immediate returns. Incentives to governments, leadership and
            ground conditions lacked for a successful pursuit of the
            ambitious reform agenda in both counties.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of -
            Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Post-Reunification
            Economic Recovery Credit for Congo were as follows: the
            outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely,
            the institutional development impact was modest, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: When a reform program
            supported by a quick-disbursing operation has a relatively
            long implementation phase, a multi-year operation with
            enough flexibility to account for evolution on the ground
            and for unforeseen technical difficulties is likely to be
            more suitable. Using adoption of an action plan as the
            tranche release condition was a way to disburse the funds
            quickly while tackling a large problem. In quick-disbursing
            operation, it is important to limit the scope of the
            immediate objectives so that they can reasonably be achieved
            during the relevant time-frame. It was not possible to make
            payment of retirees a tranche release condition because the
            Government needed the tranche to pay the retirees.
            Alternatively, the operation should be synchronized with the
            Government's budget cycle, so that adequate allocations
            could be made in the State budget to carry out the reform
            programs. Also, comprehensive programs of capacity building
            for Ministries and Government Agencies are important to
            improve implementation; donors should be prepared to provide
            assistance for this purpose. In the context of post-conflict
            fragile states, a case could be made for a hybrid lending
            instrument where funds provided by the Bank would be
            earmarked for specific purposes but the involvement of the
            Bank would not be as extensive as in investment projects.

Congo, Democratic Republic of - Post
            Reunification Economic Recovery Credit Project - release of
            the civil service retirement and internal debt tranches :
            full compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Post Reunification Economic Recovery
            Credit (PRERC) Project provides overall support to the
            Government of the for the Democratic Republic of the
            Congo's economic program for sustainable growth and
            poverty reduction. It has one cross-sectoral first tranche;
            and three floating sectoral tranches, which support reforms
            in civil service retirement, in resolution of internal debt,
            and in centralized payment of government public utilities
            bills.  All conditions for the release of the civil service
            retirement and internal debt tranches of the PRERC have been
            met and the tranches have been made available for
            disbursement.  Overall execution of the Government's
            economic program is satisfactory, and the macroeconomic
            framework is consistent with the objectives of the program.

Congo, Democratic Republic of - Post

abstracts.cdata!:
The Post Reunification Economic Recovery
            Credit (PRERC) Project supports broad reforms in critical
            areas: a) the continued implementation of economic reforms
            throughout the country; b) civil service reform, and in
            particular the retirement of staff having reached retirement
            age; and, c) completing the process of debt reduction and
            restructuring, begun under the Economic recovery Project, in
            terms of both settling arrears, and preventing the
            accumulation of new arrears. Implementation is generally
            satisfactory. The objective of the PRERC in reform of
            centralized payments, is to strengthen public expenditure
            management, and the methodology established will permit the
            government to reform its billing, and payments systems with
            other utilities. The Development Credit Agreement states
            that two general conditions must be met at the time of
            meeting the PRERC public utilities (centralized payments)
            tranche release: 1) the Association is satisfied with the
            progress achieved by the Borrower in carrying out the
            Program; and, 2) the macroeconomic policy framework of the
            Borrower is satisfactory, as measured on the basis of
            indicators, agreed upon between the Borrower and the
            Association. Overall progress in implementation of the
            PRERC-financed program is satisfactory and timely, and
            Government's commitment remains firm. The Borrower has
            met the condition for the release of the public utilities
            (centralized payments) floating tranche of the PRERC. All
            conditions for the release of the Centralized Payments
            Tranche of the Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credit
            have therefore been met. Overall execution of the program is
            satisfactory. The macroeconomic framework is consistent with
            the objectives of the program, and execution is
            satisfactory. The Government has therefore been advised that
            the Centralized Payments Floating Tranche, is now available
            for disbursement.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of -
            Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Post-Reunification Economic Recovery
            Credit (PRERC) for the Democratic Republic of Congo is
            consistent with the Bank's Transitional Support
            Strategy (TSS) discussed by the Board on July 31, 2001 and
            is an integral part of a new TSS to be discussed by the
            Board concurrently with this credit on February 26, 2004. It
            would assist the Democratic Republic of Congo in its
            economic and social recovery, in the context of the
            Government's 2004-2005 Reform, Growth, and Poverty
            Reduction Programs. Proceeds of the proposed credit would
            provide funds necessary to assist the Democratic Republic of
            Congo with foreign exchange needs.  The Credit will support
            policies that stabilize the economy and pave the way to
            environmentally and socially sustainable growth and poverty
            reduction through a number of interventions. The primary
            risks-and associated mitigating measures-are (i) renewed
            internal and or regional conflict, which is reduced by UN
            intervention and by a Bank-led multinational regional
            demobilization and reintegration program; (ii) the
            DRC's accruing new arrears on external debt because of
            the increased debt service burden in the short run, even
            though the overall debt burden in net present value terms
            has been reduced greatly; (iii) the DRC losing international
            financial support, with consequences in the country's
            ability to service debt as well as in financing necessary
            spending on social and economic rehabilitation, which is
            mitigated by the International Development Association
            (IDA's) working with other donors to assure a continued
            high level of donor financing and providing guidance for the
            measures, including the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper
            process, that will make permanent the debt service reduction
            that followed the HIPC Decision Point; (iv) insufficient
            institutional capacity, which is being addressed by
            technical assistance and capacity-reinforcing activities
            provided by IDA, the International Monetary Fund (IMF),
            United Nations Development Program (UNDP), the African
            Development Bank (AfDB), and others; and (v) private sector
            response falling short of expectation, which is mitigated by
            activities by IDA and other donors to improve the investment climate.
